status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The City of Boston acknowledges that there has been a tremendous uptick in utility work and road improvement projects the last few years. We have old infrastructure that needs to be replaced. The explosion in development requires utility service connections as well. Obviously we need to maintain our roads and sidewalks, which we do yearly. Public Works created an online reservation system called City of Boston Utility Coordination Software (COBUCS)  Nobody in the City can do work including City Departments without first entering their proposed work into COBUCS. COBUCS flags conflicts telling us to hold off before paving. . Unfortunately  emergency work and service request work may come after the coordination of the paving took place. For the most part we have greatly eliminated streets being dug up after we have paved the street. It's a breakthrough, and we are proud of that. As far as the work itself, after it has been entered into COBUCS, the Boston Transportation Department is responsible for when and where and at what time work can take place. I don't work for the Transportation Department, but I know they have a system in place that tracks active work., which allows them to either stagger permit requests, or have them hold off etc... I recommend that you create another case specifically asking for the Transportation Department to get back to you on active permits issued. Our Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU)  does create a report published on our website Monday through Friday of all active work within the City. . https://www.boston.gov/departments/public-works. Hopefully the link can be useful. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.
description:
Is there any central authority that coordinates all construction activity across the city of Boston? If not, why not? If so, is there a way to integrate all of that information in a centralized way into this app, and send us alerts as to when there will suddenly be construction on a street that we use regularly? 

I have no idea exactly where to find such information, and it is incredibly disruptive that construction projects will seem to pop up out of the blue for several days on a road I normally take, often complicating other already existing traffic challenges or construction projects. I would very much appreciate any information you have about this, and if perhaps the City Of Boston needs a user experience specialist to help design a solution to this problem, let's talk.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. National Grid is installing a new gas main.  The city encourages this type of capital upgrade work.  It will provide dependable gas service to the residents as well as  eliminate future emergency repairs. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the placement of a new gas main is well worth it.  National Grid has to install the gas main first.  Once the main has been installed, then all service connections can be made. If the city were to make National Grid pave to grade each day's trench work,  it would cause multiple seams along the trench. More importantly, every service connection needs to be cut into the trench.  If we were to pave the trench every day,  this would result in 2 by 2 patches inside the trench area, resulting in a very poor final product. In order to have the best final paving, the city allows the utility company to leave the trench down low until all service connections are made and then pave the trench all at once, resulting in a smooth, level final trench repair. Service laterals are topped within 24 hours of excavation. What the constituent is observing is the trench left down low in preparation for one continuous final paving operation. We do require that the contractor place florescent orange signs ahead of the construction informing motorists that the trench ahead is down low. The work is expected to be completed within 2 weeks. If you have any questions you can call the Inspector Rob DiMare at 781-589-2587. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. Stop signs are intended to assign right of way and would not be appropriate for speed control on Washington St. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevent cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control. Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. We invite you to document speed concerns on the Vision Zero Safety Concerns map: http://app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. The City uses this data to prioritize countermeasures and upcoming safety projects. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.
